step_by_step_thinking: The patient presents with an erythematous, scaling rash in the groin, suggestive of tinea cruris. Confirming a fungal infection requires identifying hyphae or spores. KOH examination of skin scrapings is the gold standard for diagnosing dermatophyte infections like tinea cruris. Other options (Gram stain, AFB stain) are for bacterial or mycobacterial infections, while Nikolsky's sign is relevant for blistering disorders. Documents explicitly mention KOH prep as part of tinea cruris evaluation.
